Vibe/Spin Ventures announced yesterday that it would stop publishing Blaze Magazine, the hip-hop monthly title founded in 1998. The company's chief executive, Robert L. Miller, said the magazine fell short of circulation and advertising goals.
The magazine is not audited by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
Vibe/Spin Ventures also publishes Vibe and Spin magazines, monthly music magazines.
The first issue of Blaze set records for advertising with 120 pages, according to Jesse Washington, who was then Blaze's editor. The first issue sold 250,000 copies; the second, 300,000.

The magazine had a fiery beginning in other ways: in the first issue, Mr. Washington wrote an editorial note in which he accused a rap star, Wyclef Jean, of aiming a shotgun at him and threatening to murder him if the editor gave the rapper a bad record review. Mr. Jean denied that the incident ever occurred.

Blaze's demise comes two months after Mr. Miller announced he would not sell Vibe/Spin Ventures, which he had offered for sale in October. Potential buyers balked at the reported $200 million price tag. Blaze has not been profitable, while Vibe and Spin have grown in circulation and advertising revenue in the last year.
